> Also suggest adding support for Pytest coverage reports. You will need to add a pytest.ini file (see [here](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/src/sonic-bgpcfgd/pytest.ini) for an example), and also add `pytest-cov` to the list of packages required by the tests (see [here](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/src/sonic-bgpcfgd/setup.py#L31)), and also updating the .gitignore file accordingly to ignore generated coverage files (see [here](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/blob/master/.gitignore#L13-L16)

i have added the changes, please review the changes, m not sure what kind of review do we want, so i kept html

As discussed in 10/21 sync-up mtg., LEDs are just no specific to PSUs only.
Other boards on the chassis - Supervisor, LC, FC and Fan Trays too have LEDs + chassis itself has LEDs.
Recommend having a LED daemon/service as part of PMON HLD to manage (get/set/monitor) them all and have some 'show led' CLI to display them. Note: this to be different from current ledd daemon/service which manages optics/interfaces LEDs
Recommend get_status_master_led() and set_status_master_led() as optional methods as not all platform has/support this.

> 
> 
> Recommend get_status_master_led() and set_status_master_led() as optional methods as not all platform has/support this.

Testing showed a python3 compatibility issue in our code but not related to this change.
It's just a `StringIO` import that is not compliant with py3.
I'll have a fix for this shortly. Please feel free to bug me for more python3 related changes.
I've tried some other pmon processes but unfortunately most of them are still not python3 ready.

@jleveque , after multi-asic introduction in sonic-buildimage, we introduced this bug. Kindly review it.

While I don't think this will hurt anything, we have never seen this before. It sounds like it may be a platform-specific API implementation issue that is causing this.

Acutally, it looks like `get_port_config()` is returning strings instead of integers for port indices? Is this due to a difference between reading the data from port_config.ini and the new platform.json file?

> While I don't think this will hurt anything, we have never seen this before. It sounds like it may be a platform-specific API implementation issue that is causing this.
> 
> Acutally, it looks like `get_port_config()` is returning strings instead of integers for port indices? Is this due to a difference between reading the data from port_config.ini and the new platform.json file?

Yes, @jleveque. while reading the data from port_config.ini, it converts fp_port_index to int ([link](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-platform-common/pull/111/files#diff-fba012e7b87723aab62cc0714e7aeb9cL461)) and I guess, we have to do the same for the new platform.json file. otherwise, I see error in syslog like `TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for -: 'str' and 'int' 
`
I think we need to make sure the types returned from parsing port_config.ini and platform.json are consistent.

> I think we need to make sure the types returned from parsing port_config.ini and platform.json are consistent.

@jleveque , yes yyou are right. Thats why if you see the parsing logic for port_config.ini [here](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-platform-common/pull/111/files#diff-fba012e7b87723aab62cc0714e7aeb9cL461), it converts fp_port_index to int. Let me know if it makes sense.

> yes yyou are right. Thats why if you see the parsing logic for port_config.ini here, it converts fp_port_index to int. Let me know if it makes sense.

As I said earlier, I think this change is OK, but it doesn't address the fact that the return values from parsing port_config.ini and platform.json are of different types. The burden of converting the return values falls to the consumer, which, in this case is sfputilbase.py/sfputilhelper.py. This means that all consumers will have to do the same conversion. The proper fix is to ensure that both parsers return congruent values, then anyone writing a new consumer doesn't need to be aware of this discrepancy.

@fk410167: Can you please explain how modifying the API version 1.0 plugins is related to adding support for 2.0 platform APIs?

2.0 APIs are supported in PDDF. However, some platforms still support old
plugins. We added extra attributes to these plugins in previous PDDF PRs.
Till now, these extra plugin methods were used only from PDDF utils.

There has been a need of minor changes in those extra plugin methods as per
the current PDDF utilities. E.g. the type of variable of voltage, current
and power.

-Fuzail
